standard_metadata.standard_description: Approximate the probability of a chance event by collecting data on the chance process that produces it and observing its long-run relative frequency, and predict the approximate relative frequency given the probability.

question.content: You are a space alien. You visit planet Earth and abduct $97$ chickens, $47$ cows, and $77$ humans. Then, you randomly select one Earth creature from your sample to experiment on. Each creature has an equal probability of getting selected.  **Create a probability model to show how likely you are to select each type of Earth creature.**   *Input your answers as fractions or as decimals rounded to the nearest hundredth.*  Type of Earth creature|  Estimated probability  :-: | :-: | Chicken |  Cow |  Human |

hints.content: Let's put the count of each type of Earth creature from the sample into a table.   Type of Earth creature|Frequency :-: | :-: | Chicken| $97$ Cow| $47$ Human| $77$ Total| $\blue{221}$

We get the probabilities by dividing the frequencies by the total. (Remember to round to the nearest hundredth.)  Type of Earth creature| Frequency | Probability :-: | :-: |  :-: Chicken| $97$ | $\dfrac{97}{\blue{221}} \approx0.44$ Cow| $47$ | $\dfrac{47}{\blue{221}} \approx0.21$ Human| $77$ | $\dfrac{77}{\blue{221}} \approx0.35$ Total| $\blue{221}$ | $1$

question.content: Eitan  randomly selected volcanoes to travel to and study. After traveling, he had seen $13$ cinder cone volcanoes, $18$ shield volcanoes, and $6$ stratovolcanoes.    **Use the observed frequencies to create a probability model for Eitan randomly selecting one volcano in the world on which to conduct an extensive study.**    *Input your answers as fractions or as decimals rounded to the nearest hundredth.*  Type of volcano| Estimated probability :-: | :-: | Cinder cone|  Shield|  Stratovolcano|

hints.content: Let's put the count of each type of volcano from the sample into a table.   Type of volcano|Frequency :-: | :-: | Cinder cone| $13$ Shield| $18$ Stratovolcano| $6$ Total| $\blue{37}$

We get the probabilities by dividing the frequencies by the total. (Remember to round to the nearest hundredth.)  Type of volcano| Frequency | Probability :-: | :-: |  :-:  Cinder cone| $13$ | $\dfrac{13}{\blue{37}} \approx0.35$ Shield| $18$ | $\dfrac{18}{\blue{37}} \approx0.49$ Stratovolcano| $6$ | $\dfrac{6}{\blue{37}} \approx0.16$ Total| $\blue{37}$ | $1$

question.content: Dalia owns a gravel pit. She took a random sample of rocks and counted $58$ sedimentary rocks, $213$ metamorphic rocks, and $522$ igneous rocks.  **Use the observed frequencies to create a probability model for Dalia randomly selecting one rock from her gravel pit.**   *Input your answers as fractions or as decimals rounded to the nearest hundredth.*  Type of rock| Estimated probability  :-: | :-: | Sedimentary |  Metamorphic |  Igneous |

hints.content: Let's put the count of each type of rock from the sample into a table.   Type of rock| Frequency :-: | :-: |  :-:   Sedimentary | $58$  Metamorphic |$213$ Igneous | $522$ Total | $\blue{793}$

We get the probabilities by dividing the frequencies by the total. (Remember to round to the nearest hundredth.)  Type of rock| Frequency | Probability :-: | :-: |  :-:   Sedimentary | $58$ | $\dfrac{58}{\blue{793}} \approx 0.07$ Metamorphic |$213$|$\dfrac{213}{\blue{793}} \approx 0.27$ Igneous | $522$| $\dfrac{522}{\blue{793}} \approx 0.66$ Total| $\blue{793}$ | $1$

question.content: A consumer report counted $72$ low-quality, $112$ medium-quality, and $711$ high-quality computers based on a random sample. The report went on to say that all computers, regardless of quality, are packaged identically and sold at the same price.  **Use the observed frequencies to create a probability model for the quality of the next computer purchased.**    *Input your answers as fractions or as decimals rounded to the nearest hundredth.*  Quality| Estimated probability :-: | :-: | Low|  Medium|  High|

hints.content: Let's put the count of each quality of computer from the sample into a table.  Quality|Frequency :-: | :-: | Low| $72$ Medium| $112$ High| $711$ Total| $\blue{895}$

We get the probabilities by dividing the frequencies by the total. (Remember to round to the nearest hundredth.)  Quality| Frequency | Probability :-: | :-: |  :-:  Low| $72$ | $\dfrac{72}{\blue{895}} \approx0.08$ Medium| $112$ | $\dfrac{112}{\blue{895}} \approx0.13$ High| $711$ | $\dfrac{711}{\blue{895}} \approx0.79$ Total| $\blue{895}$ | $1$

question.content: Mahnoor randomly selects times to walk into a local restaurant and observe the type of music being played. She found that the restaurant was playing country $11$ times, rock & roll $17$ times, and blues $8$ times.  **Use the observed frequencies to create a probability model for the type of music the restaurant is playing the next time Mahnoor walks in.**    *Input your answers as fractions or as decimals rounded to the nearest hundredth.*  Type of music| Estimated probability :-: | :-: | Country|  Rock & roll|  Blues|

hints.content: Let's put the count of each type of music from the sample into a table.   Type of music|Frequency :-: | :-: | Country| $11$ Rock & roll| $17$ Blues| $8$ Total| $\blue{36}$

We get the probabilities by dividing the frequencies by the total. (Remember to round to the nearest hundredth.)  Type of music| Frequency | Probability :-: | :-: |  :-:  Country| $11$ | $\dfrac{11}{\blue{36}} \approx0.31$ Rock & roll| $17$ | $\dfrac{17}{\blue{36}} \approx0.47$ Blues| $8$ | $\dfrac{8}{\blue{36}} \approx0.22$ Total| $\blue{36}$ | $1$

question.content: Grace and Jack are playing a game with a gigantic bucket of markers. Jack took a random sample of markers from the bucket and counted $12$ yellow markers, $37$ blue markers, and $1$ red marker.     **Use the observed frequencies to create a probability model for the color of the next randomly selected marker from the gigantic bucket of markers.**   *Input your answers as fractions or as decimals rounded to the nearest hundredth.*  Type of marker| Estimated probability :-: | :-: | Yellow|  Blue|  Red|

hints.content: Let's put the count of each type of marker from the sample into a table.   Type of marker|Frequency :-: | :-: | Yellow| $12$ Blue| $37$ Red| $1$ Total| $\blue{50}$

We get the probabilities by dividing the frequencies by the total. (Remember to round to the nearest hundredth.)  Type of marker| Frequency | Probability :-: | :-: |  :-:  Yellow| $12$ | $\dfrac{12}{\blue{50}} =0.24$ Blue| $37$ | $\dfrac{37}{\blue{50}} =0.74$ Red| $1$ | $\dfrac{1}{\blue{50}} =0.02$ Total| $\blue{50}$ | $1$

question.content: Anna, Irina, Avel, and Vlad are going on a road trip. The following table shows an incomplete probability model for who will be driving during any given kilometer.  Person| Probability :-: | :-:  Anna| $\dfrac18$ Irina| $\dfrac38$ Avel| $?$ Vlad|$\dfrac18$   **What is the probability that Avel will be driving during any given kilometer?**

hints.content: The individual probabilities of each person driving must sum to $1$. We know this because exactly one of the four people must be driving.

$\begin{align}\text{P(Anna})+\text{P(Irina})+\text{P(Avel})+\text{P(Vlad})&=1\\\\  \dfrac{1}{8}+\dfrac{3}{8}+\text{P(Avel)}+\dfrac{1}{8} &= 1 \\\\ \text{P(Avel)} &= 1-\dfrac{1}{8}-\dfrac{3}{8} -\dfrac{1}{8}\\\\ \text{P(Avel)} &= \blueD{\dfrac38} \end{align}$
The probability that Avel will be driving during any given kilometer is  $\blueD{\dfrac{3}{8}}$.

question.content: Sports World is open every day. Chelsey, Ivy, and James are the only employees at Sports World who can open the store.  The following graph shows an incomplete probability model for who will open the store on any given day.      **What is the probability that James will open the store on any given day?**

images.alt: A bar graph shows the vertical axis labeled Probability and the horizontal axis is labeled Employee. The bar lines shows the following: Chelsey bar line extends to 3 tenths. Ivy bar line extends to 1 tenth. James bar line is a question mark.

hints.content: The individual probabilities of each employee opening the store must sum to $1$. We know this because exactly one of the three employees must open the store.
$\begin{align} \text{P(Chelsey})+\text{P(Ivy})+\text{P(James})&=1\\\\ 0.3+0.1+\text{P(James)} &= 1 \\\\ \text{P(James)} &= 1-0.3-0.1 \\\\ \text{P(James)} &=  \blueD{0.6} \end{align}$
The probability that James will open the store on any given day is $\blueD{0.6}$.

question.content: Justin, Cam, and Ben are playing a board game where exactly one player will win. Ben estimates that Justin has a $20\%$ chance of winning each game and that Cam has a $50\%$ chance of winning each game.  **What is the probability that Ben will win the board game?**

hints.content: The individual probabilities of each player winning must sum to $100\%$. We know this because exactly one of the three players must win.

$\begin{align} \text{P(Justin wins})+\text{P(Cam wins})+\text{P(Ben wins})&=100\%\\\\ 20\%+50\%+\text{P(Ben wins)} &= 100\% \\\\ \text{P(Ben wins)} &= 100\%-20\%-50\% \\\\ \text{P(Ben wins)} &= \blueD{30\%} \end{align}$
The probability that Ben will win the board game is $\blueD{30\%}$.

question.content: After Cynthia microwaves her bowl of morning porridge, it is either too cold, just right, or too hot. She estimates that there is a $35\%$ chance that it will be too cold and a $50\%$ chance that it will be too hot.  **What is the probability that Cynthia's morning porridge will be just right?**

hints.content: The individual probabilities of the event must sum to $100\%$. We know this because exactly one of the three events must take place.

$\begin{align} \text{P(too cold})+\text{P(just right})+\text{P(too hot})&=1\\\\ 35\%+\text{P(just right)}+50\% &= 1 \\\\ \text{P(just right)} &= 1-35\%-50\% \\\\ \text{P(just right)} &= \blueD{15\%} \end{align}$
The probability that Cynthia's morning porridge will be just right is $\blueD{15\%}$.

question.content: Manny, Rachelle, and Peg race each other in carts. There are no other racers, and exactly one racer wins each race (no ties allowed!). The following graph shows an incomplete probability model for who will win any given race.      **What is the probability that Rachelle will win any given race?**

images.alt: A bar graph shows the vertical axis labeled Probability and the horizontal axis is labeled Racers. The bar lines shows the following: Manny bar line extends to 35 hundredths. Rachelle bar line is a question mark. Peg bar line extends to 25 hundredths.

hints.content: The individual probabilities of each racer winning must sum to $1$. We know this because exactly one of the three racers must win.

$\begin{align}  \text{P(Manny wins})+\text{P(Rachelle wins})+\text{P(Peg wins})&=1\\\\ 0.35+\text{P(Rachelle wins)}+0.25 &= 1 \\\\ \text{P(Rachelle wins)} &= 1-0.35-0.25 \\\\ \text{P(Rachelle wins)} & = \blueD{0.4} \end{align}$
The probability that Rachelle will win any given race is $\blueD{0.4}$.

question.content: Michael, Ronald, Lidia, Alexandra, and Catherine are sharing a basket of fries. The following table shows an incomplete probability model for who will eat the next fry.  Person| Probability :-: | :-: | Michael| $0.3$ Ronald| $?$ Lidia| $0.1$ Alexandra|$0.32$ Catherine|$0.1$   **What is the probability that Ronald will eat the next fry?**

hints.content: The individual probabilities of each person eating the next fry must sum to $1$. We know this because exactly one of the five people must eat each fry.
The probability that Ronald will eat the next fry is $\blueD{0.18}$.
